title: Thursday, 14th April, 2016

felt like a bid story...

Hm. This is all most unsatisfactory.

Entertainment One Ltd (ETO:LSE): Last: 187.80, up 29.2 (+18.41%), High: 191.00, Low: 164.90, Volume: 2.14m
11:11 am
BE

As per Bloomberg ............

BE

http://www.bloombe...-entertainment-one

BE

ITV Plc is pursuing a takeover of Canadian film distributor Entertainment One Ltd., according to people with knowledge of the situation.
The London-based broadcaster has held talks with Entertainment One about a possible deal, the people said, asking not to be identified as the discussions are private. Entertainment One distributed Oscar-winning film “Spotlight” and owns licensing rights to kids’ cartoon “Peppa Pig.”
No final decision has been made, and discussions may not result in a transaction, the people said.

11:11 am
BE

And as per Entertainment One ........

BE

Comment on Press Speculation

Entertainment One notes the press speculation regarding a potential offer.

No approach has been received by eOne.

BE

Now, the second sentence in that response just doesn't seem to tally with the second sentence of the Bloomberg report.

11:12 am
BE

It's not a nuanced denial, as we often see in these cases. It's just straight-up denying an approach.

BE

Which is ....... odd.

BE

Also, nothing from ITV.

11:12 am
ITV PLC (ITV:LSE): Last: 242.30, up 2.1 (+0.87%), High: 243.40, Low: 239.70, Volume: 5.51m
BE

The Takeover Code's pretty clear on ITV needing to say something here if it's working on a deal, irrespective of whether an approach has been made.

BE

2.2 WHEN AN ANNOUNCEMENT IS REQUIRED
d) when, after a potential offeror first actively considers an offer but before an approach has been made to the board of the offeree company, the offeree company is the subject of rumour and speculation or there is an untoward movement in its share price and there are reasonable grounds for concluding that it is the potential offeror’s actions (whether through inadequate security or otherwise) which have led to the situation;

11:13 am
BE

(Full code here: http://www.thetake...s/2008/11/code.pdf )

BE

So either they're in the process of going pens down, and we might get a "not, however, currently" statement later.

BE

Or .... well, that's just one of many possibilities, only one of which is a bid.

11:15 am
BE

Retracing a little, though ..... Why would ITV want the turkey factory anyway?

PM

hahaha

BE

It's largely a distributor, which ITV isn't.

11:16 am
BE

And it uses an ... um .... intricate Canadian tax structure to make the most of creative-industry subsidies ....

BE

Which, one assumes, ITV couldn't.

BE

Though I have to say, some of the sellside think it works.

11:17 am
BE

Mostly those with a rather top-down view of Entertainment One, I suggest.

BE

Here's Jefferies.

BE

The deal, in our view, would be strategic and opportunistic as it would diversify ITV's business away from advertising revenues. This would fuel ITV's next phase of growth as a content player which is attractively positioned given the anticipated consolidation in the European media space led by distributors and telcos.

ITV's balance sheet is flexible. Entertainment One's share price has almost halved in 12 months to 159p due to the recent refinancing. The timing would be opportunistic for ITV. The company is currently valued at c.£672m and has c.£300m of net debt. In FY15, Entertainment One generated revenues of c.£785m and EBITDA of c.£107m. If we assume a c.25% premium and acquisition price of c.£1bn, ITV will need to lever up to c.1x-2x which is reasonable. On FY17E EPS, the acquisition could be c.10% accretive.

11:17 am
BE

Entertainment One's content portfolio. It is a global production business with exposure through television, family and film. The value of the content library as at 31 March 2015 is over $1bn which includes Peppa Pig, The Mark Gordon Company, greater than 40k film titles and greater than 45k music tracks. Entertainment One is guiding for a better film slate for FY17E, firepower available for targeted acquisitions and to double the size of the business by 2020.

BE

Singer, not so much.

BE

(And I recommend Singer's work on E1, incidentally.)

11:18 am
BE

From our perspective we would be surprised if ITV would want to buy the whole of ETO. As a starting point the TV assets would be of interest to ITV, but Film is not its natural territory and this is a very significant size business. Even the TV assets may not fit correctly given ETOs shape/structure and with a large component of profit being derived from one children’s product (Peppa Pig). We clearly have concerns about ETO’s weak cash generation and we would question whether ITV investors would want to dilute the cash performance of ITV. While the shares may see a little short term benefit this is likely to wane rapidly if there is no supportive factual confirmation. Our view based on fundamentals remains unchanged at this time.

BE

Peel Hunt also.

BE

We would not be surprised if ITV was interested in the TV production assets, but do not expect it to have long-term interest in Film distribution or children’s IP. Market frustration with ETO cash flows and communication has left the shares modestly valued, and so vulnerable. Corporate action is a more realistic mechanism for closing the headline value gap than trading outperformance. For ITV, the relative scale makes this a modest risk event. For ETO it is high risk. Whither the share price should the ITV bid now not appear?

11:18 am
BE

Metrics: Deals for TV production assets have taken place c9.5x to 13.5x (max for Talpa). If we look at FY2017 forecasts for ETO, EBITDA from TV (including (Peppa Pig) is set at £99m. If we value this on say 10.5x, it suggests £1.04bn. Film distribution is trading weakly, so say 5x EBITDA of £56.7m suggests a value of c£283m. Let’s assume no cost for head office. So an EV of c£1.32bn. Less significant minorities (Mark Gordon and Peppa Pig) of say £150m and net debt of £334m, including IPF. This would give an equity value of £840m or c£2 a share. For context, ITV will have EBITDA in FY2017 of £1.07bn and net cash of £259m

BE

Advantages to ITV: Entertainment One offers ITV substantial TV production assets, not least is the majority share in Mark Gordon Associates. We would not expect ITV to be interested in the film distribution. Additionally, we would argue ITV should sell Peppa Pig (we see the maximum value achievable as the product enters the US market, remember Bob the Builder). ITV would not need to overpay given the weak levels of support for ETO as a free-standing company and given the cash flow profile and communication issues of last year (on downgrades refinancing and acquisitions). The deal itself, if £1.3bn, is about right and not a major risk for ITV. ETO is forecast to generate c.£105m NOPAT pre-minorities in FY2017, which net of funding would give c£40m to £60m uplift to ITV (tax and synergies are guessed at) c 5% upgrade. ITV’s own strong balance sheet and prodigious cash flows would easily fund the deal before net disposal receipts. ITV’s own financial controls and management reputation would resolve potentially the short comings in the existing Entertainment One Equity story.

BE

Low risk/high risk: Today’s news is relatively low risk for ITV. But we are entering a high-risk phase for ETO. What price will key ETO shareholders hold out for? What happens if ITV is seen to take a close look and then walk away? ETO recommendation and target price: We leave our £2 share target price and Add recommendation unchanged today. If the market price approaches that £2 level, investors will need to be realistic about the risk/reward balance sans bid.

11:20 am
BE

And Liberum falls between the two.

BE

Buying Entertainment One would significantly build ITV's content reach but in a different direction to what it has done by buying content assets. EOne'a business model is effectively like that of a VC firm but for content I.e. It helps to finance films and TV programmes by (mainly) independent producers and, in returns, takes the distribution rights for that content in certain companies. That is a business model that we like as the growing number of subscription platforms (Netflix, Amazon etc) is increasing demand for content per territory so it should be growing business fundamentally. The main competitors would be Vivendi's (HOLD, TP €21) Studio Canal and the likes of DHX, Dreamworks and Lionsgate. Buying EOne would also mean that ITV would acquire the rights for Peppa Pig, where EOne has a 85pc stake and which is an extremely valuable product, given its global success.

The two questions we would have if ITV did buy EOne are (1) what would be the situation regarding the Canadian tax credits that EOne receives for help finding programmes and (2) on cash flow, investors typically have difficulty understanding how E One's cash flow mechanics work and the amount of risk the company takes funding programmes (E One states the risk is limited because of the tax credits situation). One possible option ITV may pursue – if it did buy EOne – would be to divest of the films business, which is more volatile and which would seem to fit in less with its content strategy.

BE

Personally, awaiting ITV to break its silence, I'd not be chasing the rally from here. But it's your money.

BE

We've talked rather a lot about Burberry's strategic cul-de-sac of being neither super-luxury nor mass market, and whether Mr Bailey is the man to find a path between the two.

BE

As per today, Q4 retail is down 5%

BE

Against flat in Q3, and consensus was for -1%.

11:27 am
BE

Guidance seems to edge 2017 back by about 4%.

BE

Here's RBC

BE

Retail weaker than expected
4Q16 retail comps for the period ended March 2016 declined by 5% (vs. consensus -1%) versus 3Q comps at 0% illustrating a sequential decline. Asia
Pacific retail comps declined by mid-single digit, primarily impacted by the 3rd successive quarter of Hong Kong declines in excess of 20%. Mainland
China, Korea and Japan were highlighted as being positive. Continental Europe slowed as expected in 4Q as footfall from travelling consumers
slowed, whilst the UK and Middle East remained difficult throughout 2H. The US market remains volatile, with uneven demand patterns from local
customers, and sales to tourists down double digit.
FY17 PBT down mid-single digit percentage as company guiding bottom end of consensus range
We expect PBT consensus for FY17 is likely to be cut by mid-single digit, as the company now guide towards ‘the bottom of the range of analysts’
expectations’ despite a step up in FX benefit to £60m in the year, however excludes potential incremental plans to be announced in May. Underlying
cost inflation pressures clearly persist, and in a challenged revenue growth environment we expect the company to present further cost cutting
initiatives at the Preliminary results in May. We think the magnitude of cost savings may be limited given all cost cutting implemented last fiscal year
and our belief that management will ring fence marketing investment and brand elevation investment in the US and Japan.
Wholesale guidance for 1H17 is -10% (vs. -1% in 2H16), which shows sequential deterioration and reflects cautious ordering and tight inventory
control by US department stores - we currently forecast down 2%. Retail net space contribution is expected to be low SD, which is broadly in line with
our estimates. Licensing revenue guidance looks for -£20m vs. RBC estimate of -£15m

11:28 am
BE

And SocGen.

BE

Overall, the performance is mediocre (and should weigh on the stock today),
particularly the comp. store showing which points, on SGe, to falling volumes and to no
material mix and price effects. The PBT 2017 indication is not positive, and should lead to
at best unchanged estimates in the market (consensus at c.£432m according to the
company and c.£443m according to Datastream), even after factoring in a few tens of £
millions of opex cuts, on top of last year’s c.£25m.

BE

And Morgan Stanley, which is shop.

11:29 am
BE

A challenging Q4: LFL of -5% is below expectations. Burberry has released
its 2H16 trading update for the period ending March. Q4 Retail LFL has come
in at -5%, indicating further deterioration vs. Q3 (flat) and representing a miss
vs. consensus expectations of c.-1%. Wholesale revenues in 2H were down -1%
underlying, broadly in line with company guidance. While market expectations
came down over the course of the quarter in light of a more challenging
operating environment highlighted by peers, we believe that the market will be
negatively surprised by this release.
Comp deteriorated across all regions. The LFL decline came from a
slowdown in Europe (-5% Q4 MSe) due to a contraction in tourist traffic,
particularly by Chinese tourists. Americas also slowed in 4Q (-3% MSe), due
to lackluster demand from the domestic US consumer combined with lower
tourism spend. Asia Pacific was down again mid-single digit: the continued
deterioration in HK/Macau (down over -20%) was partially offset by positive
growth in Mainland China, Korea, and Japan.
Despite the LFL miss, FY16 PBT guidance of c.£420-425m was confirmed.
Management expects FY16 adj. PBT to be "broadly in line with analysts'
expectations" (£423m). This takes into account c.£80m of savings initiatives
(discretionary costs and performance-related pay) and an FX benefit likely to
be in the region of £15m (vs. £10m indicated in January).
However, the cautious FY17 outlook implies a c.5% PBT consensus
downgrade. Management provided a new FY17 outlook, indicating a
continued challenging demand environment and underlying cost pressure. Key
items include: i) low single-digit % contribution from new Retail space; ii)
Wholesale down -10% in H1 reflecting a cautious ordering attitude and a
rationalisation of the Beauty network; iii) £60m FX benefit on adj. PBT; iv)
Licensing revenue down by c.£20m, mainly due to Japan. All in all,
management expects FY17 adj. PBT to be at the bottom of the current
consensus range (~£405m) vs. an average of £428m, implying a c.5%

BE

downgrade.
Guidance excludes any potential benefits from the upcoming
efficiencies plan – although little information is known at this stage.
Management is expected to provide a concrete plan in May to offset the
ongoing margin pressure, including productivity initiatives and a revision of
the investment plan and capital structure. While the new guidance excludes
any benefits generated by the new plan, we note that little information is
known at this stage, making it hard to quantify any potential savings.
We cut our forecasts by 6-7% and lower our PT to 1,200p. Our new
estimates reflect a more cautious outlook and lower-than-expected top line
guidance: our U/L revenue growth for FY17 moves down from +3% to -1%.
We assume a 150bps EBIT margin decline (to 15.1%) and a new PBT of £402m
(down from £425m). Given the ongoing deterioration in the operating
environment and the limited visibility over the implementation (and the
timing) of new cost or productivity initiatives, our base case assumptions do
not factor in significant efficiency benefits in FY17.

PM

If they are shop, they are sounding pretty short of information

11:30 am
BE

Well, yes. None of this answers the strategic questions overhanging Mr Bailey.

BE

BE

Smiths Group PLC (SMIN:LSE): Last: 1,108, down 5 (-0.45%), High: 1,118, Low: 1,107, Volume: 167.73k
BE

I could go on.

BE

In terms of today's update ..... UK fine, international still terrible.

11:39 am
BE

Peel Hunt, I guess.

BE

Mothercare’s Q4 IMS is in line with our forecasts and we expect
full year profits to come out in keeping with our bottom of the
range PBT forecast of £19.2m, representing yoy growth of c40%.
For 2017, a more downbeat assessment of international prospects
leads us to downgrade FY2017 PBT by c12% to £26.6m (+39%
growth yoy). We expect to sit top of the range, reflecting our
positive views on the UK recovery, underpinned by double-digit
uplifts on refurbished stores and a vastly improved retail
proposition. The shares will be hit hard this morning; we would
Buy on weakness.

BE

Q4 UK LFL sales +2.1%, a good outturn for the year, with online sales +5.1%
against a tough comparative. Mothercare stores are now delivering positive LFL
sales growth in their own right, for the first time since 2008 by our reckoning.
Another quarter of gross margin improvement, driven by the group’s stronger full
price trading proposition. The key point for us is the performance of the
refurbished stores. Management has completed c40% of trading space and
expects to have the entire estate updated within 18 months. The average sales
uplift remains double digit, which underpins our LFL forecast of 4% for next
year and our expectation that the UK will be profitable. Management talks more
confidently about reaching breakeven in FY2017, although we believe the
business performance has potential to be stronger.
International retail sales fall 10.8% on translation, down 9.7% in local
currency, in line with PHe. Oil-related economies remain weak, with currency
impact on top. European sales are broadly flat overall, helped by continued
growth in Russia. Franchise partners continue to open space across the Middle
East, reflecting confidence in the medium-term opportunity.
FY2016 in line, downgrades to FY2017. Mothercare expects to deliver FY2016
PBT in line with expectations. We sit bottom of the range at £19.2m,
representing profit growth of c47% yoy. For 2017, we had previously forecast a
flat profit outcome for international. More prudently, we now assume a 9% fall in
revenues, which will translate to an equivalent fall in EBIT contribution and a
PBT downgrade of £3.4m to £26.6m, still representing yoy profit growth of
c39%. We expect our forecast to sit at the top of the new range, due to our
optimistic expectations for the UK performance, underpinned by the strong uplift
in refurbished space.
Buy on weakness. We expect the shares to be hit hard this morning, reflecting
international downgrades across the market. We view this as a cyclical setback to
the international business, rather than a fundamental weakness. Indeed, the
strength of the franchise model means Mothercare is well protected from an
operational gearing perspective. Looking ahead, plans remain on track to deliver
a transactional online platform across the international business in 12-18 months’
time, which we believe will be a major catalyst for the business.

PM

Fidelity gave us the benchmark -- cutting private co valuations by 30%

PM

I see Neil Campling of Aviate is going in boots first

PM

Rocket have been keen to promote a strategy of greater financial disclosure and show a clear path to profitability. In our view, the FY 2015 results this morning show the opposite. And the simple fact is that the number one key KPI, LPV (Last Portfolio Value), REVERSED. Rocket has adjusted some of the segments but when looking through the detail Rockets LPV fell from €6.06bn at the end of November to €5.96bn at the end of March. This despite there being four new funding transactions during the period concerned. When looking at the details of the increases: Home24 saw last financing round valuation increase by just 4% between raises (ten months) and Linio’s valuation actually fell, by 12%. Both in the stable of ‘Proven Winners’. And Linio’s net revenue growth FELL -37.8% YoY in Q4 2015 and despite ‘total customer’ growth of 76% in Q4 2015 there was just 35% growth in ‘active customers’, a fast deceleration from 144% in Q4 2014. And for an alarming negative EBITDA margin of -130% (Q4 15).

11:51 am
PM

As well he might

PM

Now the headlines attempt to focus on revenue growth as ever at the group level but this does mask that many of the underlying businesses have seen huge ramp in costs. Rocket are keen to highlight, in this flagship HelloFresh business, the outstanding 338% net revenue growth in 2015. However, this was driven by a huge increase in costs. Adjusted EBITDA LOSSES rose at the rate of 600%. Back in H2 2014 Hello Fresh had adjusted EBITDA losses of €9.6m. Fast forward to just the last three months of 2015 and this ramped to an adjusted EBITDA loss of €34.3m (Q4 2015). HelloFresh "product optimization" and marketing ramp (the $30 voucher cards at the subway stations) are given as factors in declining margins (from -6% EBITDA margin in Q4 15 to -34% in Q4 15. What about the other food businesses, FoodPanda and Delivery Hero? Well FoodPanda’s EBITDA losses (-€30.3m Q415) are almost 4x the size of the absolute number of net revenues (€8.3m Q4 15). See chart below. And Rocket blame an impact of one-offs and “seasonal effects”. (Should we really have seasonal effects for a supposed hyper growth early stage business like this?).

PM

There's lots more from Campling

11:51 am

But you'd best ring up Aviate for that

Brexit and stamp duty, of course.

BE

Here's Canaccord.

BE

Given the uncertainties in relation to the upcoming Brexit vote, the less favourable tax
environment for Buy to Let coming in recently and weaker Central London Prime market,
it is not totally surprising that Surveyors expect sales rates and new Buyer Enquiries to
slow off in the near term. However, the underlying fundamentals remain very strong in
terms of the structural under-supply, the UK economy and government support.
While the rate of increase in sales rates may slow in the near term, we still expect
good levels of sales in absolute terms for the UK house-builders and recent comments
on the start to the year support this. Pricing momentum, outside of Central London,
is also expected to remain positive. With very strong forward order books combined
with a good start to the year so far, consensus forecasts for the UK house-builders
look well supported and resilient to some potentially slower near-term sales rates and
uncertainties.
We would also expect the typical product being sold by the new house-builders to see
better trends than the wider secondary housing market. Overall the sector looks well
positioned (strong balance sheets, overall favourably longer-term industry outlook,
government support and strong forward order books) to cope with any potential nearterm
uncertainties, in our view. As its faces negative sentiment around these nearterm
uncertainties, we believe that the sector offers attractive buying opportunities,
particularly on a medium-term view.

And in terms of Persimmon ....... It's okay.

BE

Here's Davy.

BE

Today’s trading statement from Persimmon shows that new home builders are seeing a relatively buoyant trading environment despite worries regarding Brexit and the new buy to let rules. Overall, there is little new from the statement.
AGM statement broadly in line
Ahead of its AGM later today, Persimmon has released a trading statement showing continued strong sales. The weekly private sales rate for the period from the start of the year to date was 6% ahead of last year; this has eased somewhat from the +13% seen in the first seven weeks of the year.
Persimmon has opened 75 of the 100 new sites planned for the first half of the financial year. It is now trading off 370 active outlets, and management continues to focus on driving this number towards 400 by the end of 2016. This will underpin volume growth for the full year (Davy: 5%).
Total forward sales taken, including completions, were £2.15bn – 8% higher than the same period last year. The forward order book now contains 7,598 units at an average selling price of c.£220,000. Overall, the group is in a strong position to make good progress over future periods.
